abstracts.cdata!:
The Tonga Education Support Project aims
            to establish a consistent and equitable mechanism that will
            empower schools and communities to improve the quality of
            schooling at the primary and secondary school levels, and to
            produce an upward trend in educational outcomes. Despite the
            successful implementation to date, the extension of the New
            Zealand Agency for International Development (NZAID) grant
            is necessary because of the nature of the school grant
            funding scheme in Tonga. Funding is allocated to schools
            once annually in late June. Once the schools receive their
            allocation, they expend the funding over time. They are
            monitoring the situation to ensure that a four month
            extension provides adequate time to expend the grant funds.
            Extension of the International Development Association (IDA)
            credit is necessary due to the late start made by Government
            of Tonga (GoT) in deciding to use the credit financing to
            allocate maintenance and rehabilitation grants to selected
            schools. A 12 month extension of the closing date should
            allow these larger maintenance and rehabilitation grants to
            be fully executed. An action plan for implementation of the
            program is attached and will be monitored.

6311534.trustfund:
TF054013-NZ TRUST FUND FOR TONGA
            EDUCATION SECTOR SUPPORT PROJECT - BANK EXECUTE,TF054014-NZ TRUST FUND FOR TONGA
            EDUCATION SECTOR SUPPORT PROJECT - RECIPIENT EX,TF058270-PHRD STAFF GRANT PROGRAM -
            MASAHIRO MATSUMOTO

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tonga Education Support Project aims
            to establish a consistent and equitable mechanism that will
            empower schools and communities to improve the quality of
            schooling, producing an upward trend in educational
            outcomes. The project consist of the following components:
            1) will first develop a capacity within Ministry of
            Education (MoE), specifically with respect to the Tonga
            School Grants Program (TSGP) that will be financed under
            component two, to: (i) critically analyze policy options;
            (ii) establish project priorities; and (iii) develop project
            specific rolling plans based on sector priorities, assessed
            project performance (results), the efficient allocation of
            resources and consultative dialogue with stakeholders.
            Secondly, it will provide a policy and regulatory framework
            for the TSGP; 2) will establish the Tonga School Grants
            Program. Through TSGP, the Tonga Education Support Project
            (TESP) will finance improving the quality of schooling and
            removing inequities in access to quality schooling by way of
            a program of grants that allows schools to: (i) gradually
            meet government imposed school quality standards (MSS); and
            (ii) finance non-salary inputs that they and their
            communities determine necessary to improve school and
            student performance output. All primary and junior secondary
            schools will, over the course of the Tonga Education Policy
            (EPF), participate in the results-based TSGP. The amount of
            each school grant will be governed by a funding formula that
            reflects: (i) enrollment; (ii) the extent to which the
            school meets or exceeds the National Minimum Service
            Standards (MSS); (iii) Government's assessment of the
            schools service delivery capacity (degree to which the
            school is disadvantaged and/or its community is
            under-served; and (iv) needs expressed in the school's
            three year rolling development plan.
